DIALOGUE BEFORE: DLC04Mason_TA: This guy? Are you sure Gage?
RESPONSE TEXT: You better know what the hell you're doing.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04Gage: Hey, we talked about this!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Good. You're either smart or you value your life. Either way, that's exactly what I wanted to hear.
RESPONSE TEXT: Now, if you're really looking to get on my good side...
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: There's no shortage of work around here, so if you're looking to prove you've got what it takes... you know where to find me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Looks like you're already a step above Colter. I'll see how this plays out... for now.
RESPONSE TEXT: But, if you change your tune and decide to play nice...
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: There's no shortage of work around here, so if you're looking to prove you've got what it takes... you know where to find me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Of course. Just remember to think about it like this: how much do you value your life?
RESPONSE TEXT: Then, when you realize just how much...
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: There's no shortage of work around here, so if you're looking to prove you've got what it takes... you know where to find me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DisciplesLeader: Now, if you're really looking to get on my good side...
RESPONSE TEXT: There's no shortage of work around here, so if you're looking to prove you've got what it takes... you know where to find me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Last I checked, I'm the Overboss.
RESPONSE TEXT: You survived the Gauntlet, you killed Colter, with Gage's help, of course.
So sure, you're the "Overboss," but that title hasn't meant anything for a long time now.
If Gage thinks that'll change overnight, he's dead wrong.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Watch it, lady. I'm no one's pet.
RESPONSE TEXT: Really? Gage made Colter, and now here you are. I'm just calling it as I see it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: And what are you? His grandma?
RESPONSE TEXT: Heh. If I was, I would've slit that little suckup's throat a long time ago.
Gage will never be one of us. He's a failure. He's lucky we're giving him a second chance.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Pet Project? What's that supposed to mean?
RESPONSE TEXT: Gage didn't say anything?
Apparently, we're not good enough to run this place ourselves. Gage wanted to bring in his own little puppy to replace Colter.
But I guess training a puppy is way easier than getting us to do what he wants.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default:  If Gage thinks that'll change overnight, he's dead wrong.
RESPONSE TEXT: Every one knows we all wanted Colter dead. 'Course if I had my way, it would have been a slow, painful process.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.
SCRIPT NOTES: Relishing the words: slow, painful / Amused

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Colter thought some sort of rule or code made him untouchable... but he found out he was wrong... the hard way.
RESPONSE TEXT: Although, I could give him a little credit. He built the Gauntlet after all.
Of course, it was total shit at first. No imagination, but we spiced it up a bit.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DisciplesLeader: Every one knows we all wanted Colter dead. 'Course if I had my way, it would have been a slow, painful process.
RESPONSE TEXT: But whatever. Let's get this meet and greet over with.
I'm Nisha. I lead the Disciples. We've only got one rule around here, and that's keeping the peace of this... alliance.
SCRIPT NOTES: alliance said with some disgust. / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Otherwise, the way we see it, this world stopped caring about rules the moment people started dropping bombs on one another.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: This world needs rules. Otherwise, we'll never recover.
RESPONSE TEXT: Rules are dangerous because people start to trust them. They make you think you're safe, but once you turn your back... you're dead.
Colter thought some sort of rule or code made him untouchable... but he found out he was wrong... the hard way.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Rules just hold us back. We should be free to do what we want.
RESPONSE TEXT: That's what I was trying to tell Colter all long. Maybe if he listened, he'd still be around.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I bet you guys are great at parties.
RESPONSE TEXT: Side with us, you'll soon find out. Just don't slack off when it comes to actually doing your job.
We got Colter Nuka-Town, and suddenly he forgot the big picture. We both know how that turned out.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What do you mean by "keeping the peace?"
RESPONSE TEXT: It means do what you want, but don't get caught. The last thing I need is the Operators and Pack breathing down my neck.
We can take either of 'em one on one, but I don't like my odds when it comes to double duty.
So, keep the peace. It's the only rule we need.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That thing should be shut down. It's dangerous.
RESPONSE TEXT: Dangerous? People are dangerous. That thing's child's play. Just a bunch of traps and critters.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You call that a Gauntlet? More like a cake walk.
RESPONSE TEXT: Do cake walks end in death? Because if Gage hadn't helped your ass, you'd be dead right now.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I thought it was pretty impressive.
RESPONSE TEXT: Good to see the new boss at least has some taste. I might let you keep that head on your shoulders after all.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: How many lives has this Gauntlet claimed?
RESPONSE TEXT: Who's counting? It's at least enough to keep the traders busy. We like to send them in to clean out the bodies whenever things get ripe in there.
They don't always make it out alive, of course. The Gauntlet never sleeps.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Dangerous? People are dangerous. That thing's child's play. Just a bunch of traps and critters.
RESPONSE TEXT: Let's just hope Gage is right about you.
He made a lot of promises to get us here, and never followed through.
So you better not screw this up because I'm not about to tolerate another round of bullshit.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm the best there is.
RESPONSE TEXT: Willing to bet your life on that?
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm going to do things my way, whether you approve or not.
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh yeah? I just have a few things for you to consider before you go off and do things "your way."
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Depends on what you're looking for.
RESPONSE TEXT: Someone who's not afraid to get blood on their hands and make some real changes around here.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Are you questioning me? Your Overboss?
RESPONSE TEXT: Not questioning, just curious.
We were wrong about Colter. We won't make the same mistake twice.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Willing to bet your life on that?
RESPONSE TEXT: You see, the Disciples don't make empty threats, we make good on them.
We aren't swayed by caps like those spoiled brats obsessed with their hair, or those savage animals who can't behave in public.
Fuck this up, and I will kill you. Although, I admit I have even better plans for Gage.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: But... if you support us and keep your promises like a good, little Overboss, we back you, you get to live, and everybody wins.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DisciplesLeader: Fuck this up, and I will kill you. Although, I admit I have even better plans for Gage.
RESPONSE TEXT: But... if you support us and keep your promises like a good, little Overboss, we back you, you get to live, and everybody wins.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Work for me. I'll get you whatever you want.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Work for me. I'll get you whatever you want.
RESPONSE TEXT: Good. You're either smart or you value your life. Either way, that's exactly what I wanted to hear.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: Now, if you're really looking to get on my good side...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't make promises, and you'll do what I say.
RESPONSE TEXT: Looks like you're already a step above Colter. I'll see how this plays out... for now.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: But, if you change your tune and decide to play nice...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't make promises, and you'll do what I say.
RESPONSE TEXT: I once knew a man with an attitude like that. I let him live just long enough to regret it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: But, if you change your tune and decide to play nice...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'll think about it.
RESPONSE TEXT: Of course. Just remember to think about it like this: how much do you value your life?
DIALOGUE AFTER: DisciplesLeader: Then, when you realize just how much...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: And what is it you want?
RESPONSE TEXT: When you finish what Colter started, you give us control of this park. Then you set your sights on the Commonwealth.
And once the Commonwealth is yours, and believe me, with our help it will be...
You just make sure the Disciples have more than our fair share of the territories.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Work for me. I'll get you whatever you want.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: And what is it you want?
RESPONSE TEXT: Because we need each other. You give us what we want, and it's just a matter of time before everyone in the Commonwealth knows your name.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Work for me. I'll get you whatever you want.

RESPONSE TEXT: So, you're Gage's little pet project.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Last I checked, I'm the Overboss.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DLC04MQ05Mason: We gonna go up there and pull their asses out?
RESPONSE TEXT: Or even better, kill them where they stand. Either way, looks like we're about to find out... the boss is here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DLC04MQ05William: I knew that nutjob would turn on us sooner or later. So, are we storming the place or what?
RESPONSE TEXT: Both of you shut up. We're about to find out... the boss is here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DLC04MQ05Mason: You better not let them get away with this, boss. We want payback, and we want it now!
RESPONSE TEXT: And we're not talking about some slap on the wrist here. Mags and William need to pay for what they've done.
They were dead the moment they decided to take out some of my crew.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Mason: Look, boss... this is your play. You've had our back, so we'll watch yours. But you have to swear to us that Mags and William will pay.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Then let's tear them apart instead!
RESPONSE TEXT: The Disciples will make sure no one escapes. I'm going to enjoy this.
Mason's gathered up his animal goons and took the Power Plant.
If that asshole thinks he'll get away with this, he's dead wrong. I'll skin him alive and savor every minute of it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Companion: Bunch of damned savages. Should've put a knife through Mason's eye a while ago.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Just calm down and start at the beginning.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'll be calm once I get Mason's blood on my hands, but if you want a story, fine.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Nisha: While you were gone, word came back from the Commonwealth that you're favoring the Disciples and the Operators.
SCRIPT NOTES: obviously irritated time is wasting / Irritated

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I can't leave this place for five minutes without everything going to hell.
RESPONSE TEXT: If you're looking to blame someone, it better not be us.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Nisha: While you were gone, word came back from the Commonwealth that you're favoring the Disciples and the Operators.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: God damn it... sometimes I swear, this is like taking care of a bunch of children.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm going to pretend I didn't hear that because we've got bigger problems.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Nisha: While you were gone, word came back from the Commonwealth that you're favoring the Disciples and the Operators.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: How could you let this happen?!
RESPONSE TEXT: Excuse me? Babysitting the other gangs is your job.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Just calm down and start at the beginning.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'll be calm once I get Mason's blood on my hands, but if you want a story, fine.
RESPONSE TEXT: While you were gone, word came back from the Commonwealth that you're favoring the Disciples and the Operators.
Well, surprise, surprise... Mason wasn't exactly thrilled to hear the news.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Mags: He and his gang forced their way into the Power Plant. Now they've got the entire place locked down.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DLC04MQ05William: Damn right we do.
RESPONSE TEXT: Look... it's your play. We'll follow you anywhere, but you have to swear to us that Mason pays for this with his life.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I didn't build all this up just to watch him tear it down.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I didn't build all this up just to watch him tear it down.
RESPONSE TEXT: My thoughts exactly.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Mags: Time to clean house.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: He's as good as dead.
RESPONSE TEXT: Music to my ears.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Mags: Time to clean house.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Doesn't sound like he's giving us a choice. We have to take him down.
RESPONSE TEXT: Just what I wanted to hear.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DLC04MQ05Mags: Time to clean house.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I hate to lose The Pack. Isn't there some other way?
RESPONSE TEXT: They're already lost.
Mason killed some of our own, and our code says he needs to pay for what he's done.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I didn't build all this up just to watch him tear it down.

RESPONSE TEXT: It's about time you got here. The Pack's officially gone wild.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Just calm down and start at the beginning.

RESPONSE TEXT: We have to take the Power Plant back from Mags and William before they do something to it we can't fix.
Mags and William are going to pay for what they've done!
Damn Operators... never trusted those sneaky bastards.
We have to take the Power Plant back from Mason before he does something to it we can't fix.
Mason's going to pay for what he's done!
Damn Pack... never trusted those crazy bastards.
I have to admit, the park looks amazing now. You did a hell of a job, boss.
Got the park all lit up, huh? I prefer the darkness myself.
See you back at Nuka-Town, boss.
Hey. I got something for you.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but speaking to an equal (has job for player) / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Not busy? I could use you.
SCRIPT NOTES: sarcastic but friendly (has job for player) / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Hey, boss. Got a minute?
SCRIPT NOTES: Boss trying but failing not be sarcastic  (has job for player) / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Well, look who stopped by. Care to lend a hand?
SCRIPT NOTES: sarcastic, but friendly (assumes player didn't come by to help) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Got a job. I think it'll interest you.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Hey, I got something you'll want to look into.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: I got a little something you'd be perfect for.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Looking a little bored there, boss. I got just the thing to cure that.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: You look like you could use something to do, and I got just the thing.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: There you are. I need you to make some time for a job.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Busy? I have something else for you.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but speaking to an equal (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: I got another job for you, if you're interested.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but speaking to an equal (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: If you have more free time, I can use it.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but speaking to an equal (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Got something else lined up. You want in?
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but speaking to an equal (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Got another job. Interested?
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player)

RESPONSE TEXT: Boss. I got something else that requires your attention.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player)

RESPONSE TEXT: The Disciples could use you for something else. Think you can handle it?
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Got another thing, if you want in.
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: I got something else, as usual. Interested?
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Something else came up, of course. Are you up for it?
SCRIPT NOTES: commanding, but to an equal  (has job for player) / Conspiratorial

RESPONSE TEXT: Someone out there's making threats, and needs to be neutered. Metaphorically.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: A certain individual is challenging my authority out in the Commonwealth. There's a simple way to teach them respect.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Some idiot's trying to stir up trouble. I think you should show everyone how the Disciples keep trouble makers in line.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They think they've got some powerful ally. Why don't you prove them wrong - and make that powerful ally ours.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They recruited some ally out in the Commonwealth. But you know how fickle alliances can be.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They've made a friend of an old acquaintance of mine I haven't seen in quite some time. I think it's time we caught up.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I got a name on a list of potential "allies" I want you to escort back here.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They say keep your friends close and your enemies closer. Well, there's someone I need right by my side.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I think it's time someone learned just how serious we can be.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about enslaving someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Take this Shock Collar, sneak up, and snap it on when she isn't looking. Or, beat her senseless, my preference, then snap it on.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining with grim satisfaction how to put a shock collar on someone... the collar explodes if they don't comply with the owners wishes / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: I want you to collar her. Sneak up on her or beat her into submission. Either way, should be able to slap it on her without much fuss.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining with grim satisfaction how to put a shock collar on someone... the collar explodes if they don't comply with the owners wishes / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Take this Shock Collar, sneak up, and snap it on when he isn't looking. Or, beat him to a bloody pulp, my preference, then snap it on.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining with grim satisfaction how to put a shock collar on someone... the collar explodes if they don't comply with the owners wishes / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: I want you to collar him. Sneak up on him or beat him into submission. Either way, should be able to slap it on him without much fuss.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining with grim satisfaction how to put a shock collar on someone... the collar explodes if they don't comply with the owners wishes / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Apparently, one of our own has grown a conscience and tried to sneak out without facing the consequences.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Sadly, someone there turned traitor, and as you may know, all traitors must be taught a lesson.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Oddly, someone disobeyed a direct order. It's rare, so it's time to remind people just how personally I take it.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some dealer rather do business with anyone but us. As if we wouldn't notice. You're going to make that dealer regret living.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some wastelander decided to go into the information selling business. You're going to go make sure that career choice is short lived.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: An old client has taken business elsewhere. It's something that can't go unpunished.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: There's a trader that ripped off one of our outposts. An example must be made.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: An old trader thinks it's fine to badmouth us. Death is probably too good for this one. I think it's time for a little public shaming.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I got a little... problem out in the Commonwealth. You're going to solve it, and make sure no one else gets any ideas.
SCRIPT NOTES: Explaining a job to the player. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They're saying one of our own grew a conscience and tried to leave. Everyone knows if you want out, you pay with your life.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: We've got a traitor down there, and I'm feeling merciful. And by merciful, I mean skipping the torture and going straight to death.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Someone decided to act without my approval, and as punishment, I decided to spare the collar and go straight for the execution.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some trader is selling information on us. A poor life choice, especially if you're going to get caught. Time to learn the hard way.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to kill the ally of a rival gang / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some wastelander's selling secrets about us, but not for long. Just don't make it too quick. It's more satisfying when suffering is involved.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to kill the ally of a rival gang / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Somehow they managed to take one of my clients. No one cuts ties with me and lives.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to kill the ally of a rival gang / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Some trader tried to make a shit deal, then accused us of being unfair. I think death is a pretty fair response, don't you?
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some old trader thinks it's okay to trash our good name. I'm thinking you take the tongue before you take the life.
SCRIPT NOTES: Talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: There's some unfinished business in the Commonwealth. The kind that demands bloodshed, and lots of it.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They got a pretty good stash of supplies right now, but some outsiders want to make it theirs. I want you to make sure that doesn't happen.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining to player you want him to go help defend a cache of supplies destined for one of your outposts / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: They scored some supplies, but now some other group is making threats to hand them over... and no one threatens me and gets away with it.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining to player you want him to go help defend a cache of supplies destined for one of your outposts / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They had a caravan get ambushed. I trust they can handle it, but I want those supplies and I want them now.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining to player you want him to go help defend a cache of supplies destined for one of your outposts / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: My scouts found an old cache and attracted a little too much attention celebrating. Go make sure they hang on to it and it doesn't happen again.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining to player you want him to go help defend a cache of supplies destined for one of your outposts / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: One of our supply runs got ambushed. I'm sure they can manage, but I want a little insurance, just in case.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining to player you want him to go help defend a cache of supplies destined for one of your outposts / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Some trade deal's gone south. I want you to go make sure we keep what's ours and take what's theirs, along with their sad little lives.
SCRIPT NOTES: explaining to player you want him to go help defend a cache of supplies destined for one of your outposts. Emphasis on the "and" / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Apparently, some nearby neighbors aren't big on sharing when it comes to supplies. So we're just going to take them.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to go steal supplies from a rival group (and to kill any defenders) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They ran out of supplies, but I happen to know the perfect place to get them restocked.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to go steal supplies from a rival group (and to kill any defenders) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some other settlement thinks they need their supplies more than we do. Luckily, no one needs supplies when they're dead.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to go steal supplies from a rival group (and to kill any defenders) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some traders don't believe in finders keepers when it comes to stealing. It's time to put them in their place.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to go steal supplies from a rival group (and to kill any defenders) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: We've got word of some supplies we could use, and I'm never really in the negotiating mood. So you're just going to take it.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to go steal supplies from a rival group (and to kill any defenders) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Some outpost is too high and mighty to trade with us. You'd think they'd be thankful we even tried. Now we'll just kill them and take what we want.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to go steal supplies from a rival group (and to kill any defenders) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: There's a place nearby with supplies just waiting to be ours. Some may disagree, but I'm sure you won't let them live long enough to argue.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to go steal supplies from a rival group (and to kill any defenders) / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Just some Super Mutants. Nothing you can't handle.

SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Just those annoying Minutemen.
SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Gunners. Put 'em in their place.

RESPONSE TEXT: Just a few Gunners.
SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Railroad "agents." Sticking their nose where it doesn't belong.

RESPONSE TEXT: Just the Railroad.
SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: The Institute. They won't know what hit 'em.
SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Only the Institute.
SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Some nobody. I'm practically giving you this one.
SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Just some annoying idiot. Should be easy for you.
SCRIPT NOTES: answering question about mission: "who am I up against?" / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: There's no way you're done already. Don't forget you have a job to do.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player is coming back before finishing what you told him to do. / Suspicious

RESPONSE TEXT: Don't you have a little task to take care of?
SCRIPT NOTES: Player is coming back before finishing what you told him to do. / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Isn't there a job you're supposed to be doing?
SCRIPT NOTES: Player is coming back before finishing what you told him to do. / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: That's not what it looks like to me. You want to slack off, do it on your own time. Get out there and get it done.
Is that so? You've got a funny way of showing it because I'm pretty sure your job isn't here in Nuka-World.
I trust you'll get it done soon if you want to continue running this place.
If you don't think you can handle it... you can tell me. Maybe you'd rather be slumming it with the traders?
I have plenty of Disciples who'd leap at the chance to get out there and cut some throats. I'm surprised you don't share their... enthusiasm.
I got word from one of our outposts.
SCRIPT NOTES: setting up the explanation of a job -- one of the gang's hideouts has a problem she wants the player to solve / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: One of our outposts sent word.
SCRIPT NOTES: setting up the explanation of a job -- one of the gang's hideouts has a problem she wants the player to solve / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Some outpost apparently can't handle its own.

RESPONSE TEXT: An outpost in the Commonwealth put a call out.

RESPONSE TEXT: One of the outposts is having some... trouble.
SCRIPT NOTES: setting up the explanation of a job -- one of the gang's hideouts has a problem he wants the player to solve / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I was just thinking how very boring and dull the Operators' lives must be, and thought we could spice it up a bit for them.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly, about to explain how the player can help cause trouble for the rival gangs / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I think it's about time we made things more interesting for the Operators.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly, about to explain how the player can help cause trouble for the rival gangs / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I was just thinking about our dear friends in the Pack.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly, about to explain how the player can help cause trouble for the rival gangs / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I think it's about time the Pack learned a few lessons.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly, about to explain how the player can help cause trouble for the rival gangs / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Well, aren't you agreeable.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player agreed to do a job. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: That easy, huh?
SCRIPT NOTES: Player agreed to do a job. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Good.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player agreed to do a job. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: All right...
SCRIPT NOTES: Surprised the player answered yes so readily. / Suspicious

RESPONSE TEXT: Good. I need a sure thing on this.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player agreed to do a job. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Don't think I won't remember this.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - but to someone who is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: With an attitude like that, I don't see you hanging around here too long.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - but to someone who is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Maybe you should think about who you're talking to next time.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - but to someone who is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: I get it. Can't handle a little job.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - but to someone who is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: You're seriously saying no? I think Gage and I need to have a little chat.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - but to someone who is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, I'm sorry, I didn't mean to offend you by offering a job you couldn't handle.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - but to someone who is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Sarcastic

RESPONSE TEXT: And here I thought you were capable of making decisions.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - to someone who SUPPOSEDLY is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Hope that doesn't mean you're scared.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - to someone who SUPPOSEDLY is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Not interested in fun, I see. That's too bad.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - to someone who SUPPOSEDLY is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Really? The longer you stand here, the more you look like Colter.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - to someone who SUPPOSEDLY is an equal (player refuses to do the job) / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: Can't make a decision? Makes me wonder what else you can't do.
SCRIPT NOTES: annoyed, sarcastic - to someone who SUPPOSEDLY is an equal (player refuses to do the job)  / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Someone out there's making threats, and needs to be cut down to size. Think literally.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: A certain individual is challenging my authority out in the Commonwealth, and I've decided to take offense. This calls for blood. A lot of blood.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player. Emphasis on "A lot". / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Some idiot's trying to stir up trouble. I thought you could go out there and show everyone what happens when you mess with the Disciples.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They think they've got themselves some powerful ally. Why don't you show them exactly how wrong they are.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to kill the ally of a rival gang / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They recruited some ally out in the Commonwealth. But you know how bad it can be out there. Most people don't live very long.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to kill the ally of a rival gang / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: They've made a friend of an old acquaintance that I let live a while back. I think I regret that decision now, if you know what I mean.
SCRIPT NOTES: slyly asking the player to kill the ally of a rival gang / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I got a name I want you to help cross off a list.

RESPONSE TEXT: There's some... tidying up that I thought you could help with.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: I think it's time someone learned just how dangerous we can be.
SCRIPT NOTES: talking about killing someone - explaining a job to the player / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Good.

RESPONSE TEXT: I knew you'd be interested.

RESPONSE TEXT: That's what I like to hear.

RESPONSE TEXT: I figured you might be into that.

RESPONSE TEXT: Thought you'd like that.

RESPONSE TEXT: Well, that didn't take long.

RESPONSE TEXT: Your payment. Not that you need it.

RESPONSE TEXT: Here's what you're owed.
Your cut for the successful job.
Payment in full.
Here. Try not to spend it all in one place.
Not that you need this, but here. Your payment.
Here's your cut. I suppose you earned it.
SCRIPT NOTES: friendly, sarcastic. You don't think the player needs any money. He's the overboss. But fair is fair. He did do the job you asked him to. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Caps for your time. Enjoy them while they last.
Here. A few caps for the trouble.
And your payment, as expected.
For your trouble.
SCRIPT NOTES: Paying the player for a job. / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Of course. You are the Overboss, aren't you?
Obviously. Think anyone does anything for free around here? Well, heh, beside the traders.
That goes without saying.
Why? Hurting for caps? Don't worry, you'll get paid.
No...
Damn.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player hit you in combat. Calm, impressed the player hit you, reconsidering their threat level. / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Yech.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player hit you in combat. Calm but disgusted. / Disbelief

RESPONSE TEXT: Hmm.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player hit you in combat. Calm, impressed the player hit you, reconsidering their threat level. / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: I'll have your head on a pike when this over.
SCRIPT NOTES: Taunting the player in combat. / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Try not to die too quickly. I want to savor this.
SCRIPT NOTES: Taunting the player in combat. / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: If you wanted death, all you had to do was ask.
SCRIPT NOTES: Taunting the player in combat. / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: Must be my lucky day.
Your blood will do.
Ready to die?
Don't tell me I've upset you...
Not all there, are you.
Great. Worse than Colter.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player isn't responding. Annoyed, under breath. / Irritated

RESPONSE TEXT: If you side with the Disciples, the whole Commonwealth will fear us... and with fear comes power.
Don't think our cooperation means respect. I'm still seeing how this all plays out.
You've got a lot to prove. A child could fill Colter's shoes.
With those traitors gone, there's even more fun to go around.
Nuka-World's going to attract people far and wide, and we're going to bleed them dry in more ways than one.
Fine, I admit it. There really is a bit more appeal to this place when it's all lit up.
It's good to know Gage didn't screw us over a second time.
It's not everyday I like someone better alive than dead. I guess you're one of the lucky ones.
Gage's gotta be relieved you pulled through for him. Means he gets to keep his head after all.
The way you're running things, you must not value your life.
You're taking a very dangerous path,... boss.
SCRIPT NOTES: Boss said with huge disgust / SinisterSmile

RESPONSE TEXT: I wouldn't stick around. You've no idea how irritating it is, just to see you breathing.
If the Pack is going to howl all the time, they could at least be good at it.
The Operators are too obsessed with their reflections to get any real work done around here.
I hope those traders realize they're only alive because we allow it.
I can't believe we didn't deal with Colter ourselves.
I bet Gage is happy he has a new ass to kiss. Not sure how he put up with Colter all that time.
The nice thing about living inside the mountain, is not having Nuka-Cola shoved down your throat every minute.
I've heard you're responsible for a few of our neighbors' deaths. This needs to stop. You know the plan.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.

RESPONSE TEXT: I want you on a run with Dixie. You know how enthusiastic she gets. Make sure she doesn't wipe out the whole settlement.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.

RESPONSE TEXT: Savoy said you're getting sloppy. That you've been relying on psycho to complete your...tasks. This needs to stop.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.

RESPONSE TEXT: I'm putting you on guard duty, starting tomorrow.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.

RESPONSE TEXT: I've heard there's some traders passing through north of the park. I want you to get to them before the others do.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.
RESPONSE TEXT: I already did. You're just there as insurance. Now go.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.
RESPONSE TEXT: I don't want to hear your sob story. Get your shit together, or you can join her.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.
RESPONSE TEXT: It's only temporary. Lots of changes are happening, and I want our security at its best. Take it as a compliment.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Disciple: They'll never track it back to me. As far as they know, they were lost in the wasteland.
RESPONSE TEXT: Our own purposes. Salvage what you want, but I want them alive and in one piece.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Dixie: Come on, girl, you know we should run this place. Not some lil greenie Gage dragged in.
RESPONSE TEXT: We're giving him a second chance. Gage screws this up, he knows we'll skin him alive. So shut up and be patient.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Dixie: What about you big guy? Nothing to say on the matter?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Dixie: Yeah, figured as much.
RESPONSE TEXT: Both of you just get out of here. And make sure the others get the message.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Nisha: A shame. I'd love to see the look on Mags' face one more time before you took her out. Not to mention that stupid brother of hers.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Nisha: You made good on your promise, and we've got one less worthless gang to divvy up the spoils.
RESPONSE TEXT: A shame. I'd love to see the look on Mags' face one more time before you took her out. Not to mention that stupid brother of hers.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Think death is a little too good for them?

It's probably why they put up a real fight for once, not that anyone could tell.
Better to die in the fight then face the consequences of their own stupidity.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: It had to be done.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: No arguments here.
RESPONSE TEXT: So tell me. You've been Overboss a while now, followed through on your promises...
You claimed the rest of the park, got us out in the Commonwealth, and now Nuka-World's lit up like a Christmas tree.
Was it worth it?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: This is the life. Wouldn't trade it for the world.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: This is the life. Wouldn't trade it for the world.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Nisha: I only regret wasting all those plans I had for Gage. Although, I'm sure he's bound to screw up sooner or later.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: All that effort? I would have expected more.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Nisha: I only regret wasting all those plans I had for Gage. Although, I'm sure he's bound to screw up sooner or later.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That's my business.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Nisha: I only regret wasting all those plans I had for Gage. Although, I'm sure he's bound to screw up sooner or later.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Why do you care? You got what you wanted.

You were lured in here like any common wastelander. I figure you must have some thoughts on whether or not it all paid off.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: This is the life. Wouldn't trade it for the world.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You bet it is. And with this place more or less operational, all we've got to do is sit back and profit.
